column5: I fished Lake O yesterday off the Hamilton canal and never moved a rod but I did catch this coming out of the ship canal, what a surprise.    I did hear on the VHF that a Sub was coming out of the canal, My first thought was I hope this Sub knows I'm fishing out front, down-rigger cables caught on Sub and me going for a ride The harbor master was talking to the crew on the radio and said, who would ever think you would have to lift the bridge for a Sub
Saw that down the mouth of the Grand last week. Didnt have my camera with me at the time. Very cool
Now theres something you dont see every day Glad you were there to witness it.
Really interesting.  Must have been cool.
Canada is importing Weapons of Mass Destruction? Oh no!
Musta had ya there for a minute ......lol
Dat boat is probably defective eh? De ship is in for service...it don't sink good.
I heard one of the screen doors wouldn't close correctly Roy.   Art
No problem Roy, I had to make sure you guys weren`t trying to sneak up on us.
X2 Thanks Paul for the link. Some good read there. Shame if they cut them up. They'd make a good tourist attraction

Fish, they Had the USS COD here at the Cleveland lakefront for years, a WW2 submarine, I believe the one that rescued George Bush senior when he was shot down in the Pacific during the war.  I went on it for a tour of the inside as a kid, them guys were tough! I don`t know what the insides of the new ones look like, but that one seemed like a sardine can.
I think that is one of 3 pieces of crap from the Halifax Harbour that don't work.
reminds me of my favourite movie.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jr0JaXfKj68&feature=related

May 2005, the Halifax Chronicle-Herald announced that MARCOM was looking to sell Okanagan for scrap metal, along with three other Canadian Oberons laid up at CFB Halifax. MARCOM stated that the submarines were not in suitable condition to be used as museum ships and predicted that each submarine would sell for between C$50,000 and C$60,000.[1] Okanagan is to be towed to a scrapyard in Port Maitland, Ontario in 2011.
